items.content_html: As per #28157 (comment), Ellipse is missing from the Syntax part of offset-path, but is found in Values and in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape. I've added an example that matches the other shapes.
items.title: Add ellipse to offset-path Syntax

items.content_html:
Description

This is planned in #26847

The TypedArray method pages have long been outdated. No one seems to care about them because we don't see any PRs fixing bugs. This means people either read Array method pages for the detailed information, or these pages are not useful at all. At any rate it would be easier for maintenance if we only keep one copy of the information.

In this PR I've made the wording as aligned between the two sections as possible.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

items.content_html:
Description

There was a missing word (as) in the sentence:
"The browser blocks rendering until it parses all of these styles but will not block rendering on styles it knows it will not use, such the print stylesheets."

It should read:
"The browser blocks rendering until it parses all of these styles but will not block rendering on styles it knows it will not use, such as the print stylesheets."

Motivation

It makes the sentence make sense, which should benefit reader comprehension.

Additional details

N/A

Related issues and pull requests

N/A - just a typo! üòÑ
items.title: Correcting Typo on 'CSS performance optimization' page

items.content_html:
Description

Make it explicit in the documentation that if you did not use the authenticatorAttachment to filter the authenticator type during the creation of the public key credentials, all types are available to be chosen.

Motivation

It helps the reader understand this option is a filter. It also improves the consistency of the documentation as this type of reminder regarding the default behavior is continuously used along the page.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

items.content_html:
Description

Document that import declarations are hoisted.

Motivation

It's missing from the docs. I found places stating it, I tried it, and from what I gather it follows from the spec (specifics bellow). Hope it checks out!

Additional details

Other places stating it

  • PHPStorm site help article, paragraph 3
  • This entry on Exploring ES6
  • This StackOverflow answer

Broad example

I tried this and it works as expected in Firefox, Chrome, and Node 20 (and without the string name, also node 12).

index.js:

console.log("My imports:", {
    defaultExport,
    name,
    exportedValue1,
    exportedValue2,
    alias1,
    alias2,
    strName
});

import defaultExport from "./module-name.js";
import * as name from "./module-name.js";
import { exportedValue1, exportedValue2 } from "./module-name.js";
import { exportedValue1 as alias1 } from "./module-name.js";
import { default as alias2 } from "./module-name.js";
import { "string name" as strName } from "./module-name.js"
import "./module-name.js";

module-name.js:

const defaultValue = 'default value';
export default defaultValue;
export const exportedValue1 = 'an exported value';
export const exportedValue2 = 'another exported value';
export { exportedValue1 as "string name"};

console.log("This is a module side effect");

Off the spec:

We are gonna care about these two parts of the module lifecycle:

Evaluation, therefore producing the module side effects:

The module record property [[RequestedModules]] is set in ParseModule, to the value of the sintax-directed operation ModuleRequests, that returns a List with all module specifier strings that are either imported or required in "export xx from yy" statements.

module.Evaluate runs InnerModuleEvaluation(module) the first time it is called.

InnerModuleEvaluation checks that the module is in the right part of its lifecycle, and then runs itself on each of module.[[RequestedModules]], and then performs either ExecuteAsyncModule(module) (when it is asynchronous and has no pending async dependencies. The dependency modules have access to their ancestors, and can execute them when fulfilled. ExecuteAsyncModule sets up a call for module.ExecuteModule internally) or module.ExecuteModule(). module.ExecuteModule evaluates the module's parsed code.

In summary, it runs the deepest modules first.

Linking, thus binding the imported names:

The linking of a module happens before it's ran. This is asserted in ExecuteModule, where the module's [[ECMAScriptCode]] is ran, and permeates many statements, like the [[Status]] field's definition.

The module record property [[ImportEntries]] is set in ParseModule, to the value of the sintax-directed operation ImportEntries, that returns a List with the ImportEntry Record's that hold data about the imported items in the declarations of the shape "import xx from yy", those that bind names: The module where they are from, their name there, and their local names given in the importing module.

module.Link defers the actual linking to module.InnerModuleLinking(module). There, if the module is in the right part of its lifecycle, it then runs module.InitializeEnvironment(), which creates and sets a module environment in module.[[Environment]], and then creates appropriate bindings in it for each of module.[[ImportEntries]]. Before execution, ExecuteModule will set up module.[[Environment]] as the variable and lexical environments for the execution context on which to run the module's code.

We can see that the import bindings from the whole module file are set up before running the module.
items.title: Import declarations are hoisted

items.content_html:
FF117 supports the CSS Custom Highlight API behind a preference/in preview. This adds an experimental feature note.

Other docs work can be tracked in #28291
items.title: FF117 Expr.Featr. CSS Custom Highlights API

items.content_html:
1. offset-path

  • Previous syntax: offset-path: none | ray( [ <angle> && <size> && contain? ] ) | <path()> | <url> | [ <basic-shape> || <geometry-box> ]
  • New syntax: offset-path: none | <offset-path> || <coord-box>
    where:
    <offset-path> = <ray()> | <url> | <basic-shape>
    ray( <angle> && <size>? && contain? && [at <position>]? )
  • MDN page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/offset-path
  • Page updates and new <box-edge> page that documents <coord-box>: #28348
  • Prefs required to be enabled in stable Fx116 for <basic-shape> and <coord-box> parameters:
    • layout.css.motion-path-basic-shapes.enabled
    • layout.css.motion-path-coord-box.enabled
  • Bugs:
    • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1598156
    • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1837305

2. ray()

  • Previous syntax: ray( <angle> && <ray-size>? && contain? )
  • New syntax: ray( <angle> && <size>? && contain? && [at <position>]? )
  • MDN page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/ray
  • Page updates: #28348
  • Pref required to be enabled in stable Fx116 for ray(): layout.css.motion-path-ray.enabled
  • Bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1820070 (ray)

The previous ray() release note was captured in the 112 release note file. Because this function is still available only behind preference, I've removed the entry from the release notes file and added it to the 'Experimental features' file.

Related issues and pull requests

Doc issues:

  • #27747
  • #27751

Content PR: #28348
items.title: docs(relnotes): FX116 release notes offset-path and ray()

items.content_html:
1. offset-path

Previous syntax

offset-path: none | ray( [ <angle> && <size> && contain? ] ) | <path()> | <url> | [ <basic-shape> || <geometry-box> ]

New syntax

offset-path: none | <offset-path> || <coord-box>
where:
<offset-path> = <ray()> | <url> | <basic-shape>
ray( <angle> && <size>? && contain? && [at <position>]? )

  • MDN page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/offset-path
  • Motion Path spec: https://drafts.fxtf.org/motion-1/#offset-path-property
  • Codepen: coord-box example (https://codepen.io/dipikabh/pen/JjexYPo)
  • Prefs required to be enabled in Fx116 stable:
    • layout.css.motion-path-coord-box.enabled
    • layout.css.motion-path-basic-shapes.enabled
  • <coord-box> is defined in the Box Model spec (https://drafts.csswg.org/css-box-4/#keywords).
    New page: I've created a <box> data type page to document the box-edge keywords and how they are then used in different <box> types like <visual-box>, <layout-box>, <paint-box>, <coord-box>, and <geometry-box>.
    I can do a follow up PR to add examples to <box> data type page and also cleanup other related pages (covered in "Additional info"). I anyway need to do a separate PR to add spec link and BCD info.
    Additional info (click arrow)
    * clip-path syntax expands <box> to border-box | padding-box | content-box. So I've used <box> as the building block. (as also used in the Shapes spec)
    * Making a note of this here for future reference and cleanup - a lot of pages on MDN refer to the box-edge keywords
    - Box model
    - Box model in Learn
    - Shapes from box values
    - box-sizing
    - transform-box
    - background-clip
    - overflow-clip-margin mentions the <visual-box> value
    * Only a glossary page exists for Bounding box - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Bounding_box
    - Types not covered on MDN: object bounding box, stroke bounding box, decorated bounding box (svg spec: https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/coords.html#TermObjectBoundingBox)
  • Also made some minor edits to offset-position and offset pages.

2. ray()

Previous syntax

ray( <angle> && <ray-size>? && contain? )

New syntax

ray( <angle> && <size>? && contain? && [at <position>]? )

  • MDN page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/ray
  • Motion Path spec: https://drafts.fxtf.org/motion-1/#funcdef-ray
  • Codepen: updated ray syntax (https://codepen.io/dipikabh/pen/yLReQaZ)
  • Prefs required to be enabled in Fx116 stable:
    • layout.css.motion-path-ray.enabled
    • layout.css.motion-path-offset-position.enabled

Related issues and pull requests

Doc trackers:

  • #27747
  • #27751

Bugs:

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1598156 (offset-path)
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1837305 (offset-path)
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1820070 (ray)

To Dos

  • Update BCD
  • Update release notes
  • Update mdn/data
items.title: docs(css): Fx116 - syntax updates for offset-path and ray()
